# Cambridge IGCSE™

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 277, 347, 293]]<|/det|>
## ADDITIONAL MATHEMATICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[832, 277, 904, 293]]<|/det|>
0606/22  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 302, 150, 316]]<|/det|>
Paper 2  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[780, 302, 904, 316]]<|/det|>
May/June 2025  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[840, 326, 904, 340]]<|/det|>
2 hours  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 355, 393, 370]]<|/det|>
You must answer on the question paper.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 384, 359, 399]]<|/det|>
No additional materials are needed.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 418, 221, 432]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 434, 855, 604]]<|/det|>
INSTRUCTIONS- Answer all questions.- Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.- Write your answer to each question in the space provided.- Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- You should use a scientific calculator where appropriate.- You must show all necessary working clearly.- Give non- exact numerical answers correct to 3 significant figures, or 1 decimal place for angles in degrees, unless a different level of accuracy is specified in the question.- For \(\pi\) , use either your calculator value or 3.142.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 634, 212, 647]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 650, 728, 681]]<|/det|>
INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 80.- The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[430, 74, 567, 90]]<|/det|>
List of formulas 

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 106, 782, 125]]<|/det|>
Equation of a circle with centre \((a, b)\) and radius \(r\). \((x - a)^2 + (y - b)^2 = r^2\) 

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 155, 675, 173]]<|/det|>
Curved surface area, \(A\), of cone of radius \(r\), sloping edge \(l\). \(A = \pi rl\) 

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 202, 683, 221]]<|/det|>
Surface area, \(A\), of sphere of radius \(r\). \(A = 4\pi r^2\) 

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 247, 680, 275]]<|/det|>
Volume, \(V\), of pyramid or cone, base area \(A\), height \(h\). \(V = \frac{1}{3} Ah\) 

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 295, 683, 323]]<|/det|>
Volume, \(V\), of sphere of radius \(r\). \(V = \frac{4}{3}\pi r^3\) 

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 348, 655, 365]]<|/det|>
Quadratic equation For the equation \(ax^2 + bx + c = 0\), 

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[390, 367, 560, 402]]<|/det|>
\[x = \frac{-b \pm \sqrt{b^2 - 4ac}}{2a}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 446, 225, 463]]<|/det|>
Binomial theorem 

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[390, 437, 905, 480]]<|/det|>
\[(a + b)^n = a^n + \binom{n}{1} a^{n-1}b + \binom{n}{2} a^{n-2}b^2 + \dots + \binom{n}{r} a^{n-r}b^r + \dots + b^n,\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[390, 483, 770, 526]]<|/det|>
where \(n\) is a positive integer and \(\binom{n}{r} = \frac{n!}{(n-r)!r!}\) 

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 555, 217, 571]]<|/det|>
Arithmetic series 

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[390, 555, 667, 600]]<|/det|>
\[u_n = a + (n-1)d \\ S_n = \frac{1}{2}n(a+l) = \frac{1}{2}n\{2a+(n-1)d\}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 632, 217, 648]]<|/det|>
Geometric series 

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[390, 631, 570, 710]]<|/det|>
\[u_n = ar^{n-1} \\ S_n = \frac{a(1-r^n)}{1-r} \quad (r \neq 1) \\ S_\infty = \frac{a}{1-r} \quad (|r| < 1)\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 740, 158, 756]]<|/det|>
Identities 

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[390, 739, 555, 789]]<|/det|>
\[\sin^2 A + \cos^2 A = 1 \\ \sec^2 A = 1 + \tan^2 A \\ \cosec^2 A = 1 + \cot^2 A\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 829, 240, 846]]<|/det|>
Formulas for \(\Delta ABC\) 

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[390, 825, 576, 900]]<|/det|>
\[\frac{a}{\sin A} = \frac{b}{\sin B} = \frac{c}{\sin C} \\ a^2 = b^2 + c^2 - 2bc \cos A \\ \Delta = \frac{1}{2} ab \sin C\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 72, 94, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 616, 90]]<|/det|>
In this question, all lengths are in metres and time is in seconds.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 103, 918, 135]]<|/det|>
A particle \(P\) moves in a straight line such that its displacement \(s\) from a fixed point \(O\) at time \(t\) is given by \(s = (t - 4)^2 (t - 1)\) for \(t \geqslant 0\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 149, 146, 167]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 149, 858, 167]]<|/det|>
On the axes, sketch the displacement–time graph of \(P\), stating the intercepts with the axes. [2]

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 179, 902, 526]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 540, 146, 558]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 540, 494, 558]]<|/det|>
Find an expression for the velocity, \(v\), of \(P\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 556, 458, 573]]<|/det|>
Give your answer in a factorised form.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 555, 918, 573]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 144, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 818, 90]]<|/det|>
On the axes, sketch the velocity–time graph of \(P\), stating the intercepts with the axes.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 72, 920, 90]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 102, 910, 428]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 443, 148, 460]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 443, 528, 460]]<|/det|>
Find an expression for the acceleration, \(a\), of \(P\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 443, 920, 460]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 551, 144, 568]]<|/det|>
<label>(e)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 551, 850, 568]]<|/det|>
On the axes, sketch the acceleration–time graph of \(P\), stating the intercepts with the axes.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 551, 920, 568]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 580, 910, 905]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 72, 94, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 365, 88]]<|/det|>
Functions f and g are such that

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[354, 103, 551, 131]]<|/det|>
\[\mathrm{f}(x) = \frac{3x}{x + 4}\quad \mathrm{for} x > 0\]

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[354, 139, 570, 159]]<|/det|>
\[\mathrm{g}(x) = \sqrt{x + 2}\quad \mathrm{for} x > -2\,.\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 173, 359, 190]]<|/det|>
Solve the equation \(\mathrm{fg}(x) = 1\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 173, 920, 190]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 82, 94, 101]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 82, 144, 101]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 78, 680, 102]]<|/det|>
Given that \(y = 4\sin 2x\cos 2x\) , find the value of \(\frac{\mathrm{dy}}{\mathrm{dx}}\) when \(x = \frac{\pi}{6}\) .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 408, 148, 426]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 408, 485, 425]]<|/det|>
A curve has equation \(y = 4\sin 2x\cos 2x\) .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 435, 787, 460]]<|/det|>
The normal to the curve at the point where \(x = \frac{\pi}{6}\) meets the \(x\)-axis at the point \(P\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 470, 405, 486]]<|/det|>
Find the exact coordinates of \(P\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 470, 920, 488]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 92, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>5</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 146, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 72, 749, 106]]<|/det|>
A 4-digit number is to be formed using the digits 0, 2, 4, 5, 6 and 8. The 4-digit number must **not** start with 0.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 103, 610, 120]]<|/det|>
Any digit may be used at most once in the 4-digit number.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 134, 180, 152]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 134, 568, 152]]<|/det|>
Find how many 4-digit numbers can be formed.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 134, 920, 152]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 211, 180, 230]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 211, 610, 230]]<|/det|>
Find how many even 4-digit numbers can be formed.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 211, 920, 230]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 351, 180, 369]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 351, 739, 369]]<|/det|>
Find how many 4-digit numbers that are divisible by 5 can be formed.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 351, 920, 370]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 536, 146, 555]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 536, 616, 555]]<|/det|>
Solve the equation \(\left(n + 1\right)\times {}^{n + 1}\mathrm{C}_{12} = 33\left(n - 10\right)\times {}^{n}\mathrm{C}_{10}.\) 

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 536, 920, 555]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 77, 92, 95]]<|/det|>
<label>6</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 77, 700, 95]]<|/det|>
The volume, \(V,\) of a sphere is increasing at the constant rate of \(2\pi \mathrm{cm}^3 \mathrm{s}^{-1}\) .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 92, 918, 110]]<|/det|>
Find the rate of change of the surface area, \(S,\) of this sphere when the volume of the sphere is \(36\pi \mathrm{cm}^3.\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 108, 920, 126]]<|/det|>
<mark>[6]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 72, 94, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>7</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 72, 638, 90]]<|/det|>
The first three terms of an arithmetic progression can be written as

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[240, 100, 465, 121]]<|/det|>
\[2\ln \left(x^{3}\right),\quad 5\ln \left(x^{2}\right),\quad 2\ln \left(x^{7}\right).\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 134, 146, 152]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 134, 918, 170]]<|/det|>
Given that \(x > 1\), find the least number of terms for the sum of this progression to be greater than \(43\ln \left(x^{24}\right)\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 152, 920, 170]]<|/det|>
<mark>[6]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 146, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 816, 88]]<|/det|>
Given that the 25th term of this progression is equal to 408, find the exact value of \(x\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 72, 920, 88]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 73, 94, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>8</label>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 92, 902, 400]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 421, 524, 453]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows part of the curve \(y = \frac{15}{x} - \frac{5}{x^2}.\) 

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 459, 443, 475]]<|/det|>
The curve meets the \(x\)-axis at the point \(A\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 475, 440, 490]]<|/det|>
The curve has a maximum at the point \(B\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 520, 686, 537]]<|/det|>
Find the area of the shaded region enclosed by the line \(AB\) and the curve.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 552, 372, 567]]<|/det|>
Give your answer in exact form.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[881, 552, 920, 568]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 465, 88]]<|/det|>
Continuation of working space for Question 8.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 85, 107, 103]]<|/det|>
<label>10</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 78, 918, 122]]<|/det|>
The first three terms, in descending powers of \(x\), in the expansion of \(\left(3x^2 - a\right)^n \left(1 + \frac{1}{x^2}\right)^2\) can be written as \(729x^{12} + 972x^{10} + bx^8\), where \(a\), \(b\) and \(n\) are constants.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 136, 348, 152]]<|/det|>
Find the values of \(a\) , \(b\) and \(n\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 135, 920, 153]]<|/det|>
<mark>[9]
